item.title: Fair Wages for Workers with Disabilities Act of 2013
To phase out special wage certificates under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 under which individuals with disabilities may be employed at subminimum wage rates.
Fair Wages for Workers with Disabilities Act of 2013

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Workforce Protections.
Referred to the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text:
Fair Wages for Workers with Disabilities Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Labor to discontinue issuing to any new profit or non-profit or governmental entity special wage certificates (which permit individuals with disabilities, including individuals employed in agriculture, to be paid at lower than minimum wages).

Prescribes requirements for a three-year phase-out of all certificates.

Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to repeal authority and requirements for the issuance of such certificates three years after enactment of this Act. Requires revocation of any certificates remaining at that time.

bill.title: Fair Wages for Workers with Disabilities Act of 2013

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Workforce Protections.

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: By Mr. HARPER:H.R. 831.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:``clause 3 of section 8 of article I of the Constitution''.[Page H660]

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
